prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 43 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 43 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 43 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
2. Agricultural subsidies should promote sustainable, pesticide and antibiotic-free production.
3. I don't trust what scientists say about climate change.
4. There's not much point in me doing anything to make agriculture more sustainable. No-one else is going to.
5. “Actions on the food system in Switzerland will lead to increased imports and shift of the pollution abroad”
6. The main focus of planning for adaptation should be to prepare the food system for extreme weather events, such as drought and flooding. 
7. The Swiss food system is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
8. I don't trust what I hear about climate change from government.
9. Sustainable agriculture increases prices and harms consumer freedom. The production should be adapted to what people demand.
10. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it
11. I believe that the difference we can have as an individual, in Switzerland, is so minimal that our actions are worthless.
12. It is important to plan for migration by people displaced by malnutrition and famine.
13. The Swiss food system depends on imports from other countries, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
14. Agriculture is already very sustainable. Swiss farmers are on the right track
15. There is not enough information to definitively establish if the link between the agri-food system and climate change is real.
16. We should develop short distribution channels and support local production instead of supporting big agrifood corporations
17. Planning for food system adaptation needs a holistic approach, considering a whole range of issues, instead of focussing on individual issues. 
18. It is NOT necessary to engage with the community when deciding what are the most important issues for planning for food system changes.
19. I'm not going to do anything to address the impacts of the agri-food system because it is not a major issue.
20. We need actions to protect inhabitants and the biodiversity from harmful pesticide.
21. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
22. We need to focus on adaptation actions that are concerned with the economic future of the country.
23. The community should be involved in discussions about food system adaptation.
24. Some communities are more affected than others by the global agri-food system, but this is not a priority issue.
25. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than environmental ecosystems.
26. I don't know what to do. I'm very concerned and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic shortlist of things that would really make a difference.
27. The negative effects of the climate change on local commerce should be taken into account.
28. Strong regulation of food production will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
29. There is not enough information to definitively say that climate change is real.
30. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy
31. As long as we use animals in agriculture, it cannot be sustainable
32. “Food accessibility (price) and security (availability) is NOT COMPATIBLE with a sustainable food system”
33. It is important to support smal land local farming as they have the fewest resources to deal with impacts of climate change. 
34. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
35. “Intensive food production can go along with the protection of the environment and health”
36. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illness and death caused by intensive use of pesticides/antibiotics
37. Climate change will not be a problem because there will be technological solutions available.
38. If Switzerland reduces greenhouse gases of its food system it won't make a difference.
39. It's difficult to trust what comes out in the media on the issue of climate change.
40. I am happy to pay a higher price for local or organic food products
41. We need to deal with the water pollution issue through measures such as reducing fertilizer and pesticide use.
42. Products that use environmentally harmful ingredients, such as palm oil, should be taxed in the same way as tobacco products.
43. “Farmers already suffer enough from strict rules and paperwork. Family farmers should have more liberties”

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Policies that involve a radical sustainable food regulation (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the importation of food related product that employ non-sustanable approaches, exclusively incentivising organic agriculture)
2. Preparing for climate risk for food production through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change.
3. Adaptation policies and expenditure. Planning controls and emergency response programs.
4. Policies that involve a moderate sustainable regulations (e.g., banning certain types of pesticides, incentivising organic agriculture)
5. Leave the policy settings as they are.
6. Policies that create incentives for local producers to produce sustainable food (e.g., subsidies or tax breaks for local farmers who produce organic products)
7. Policies that emphasise fewer regulations (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulation)

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I prioritize resilient technologies and adaptation, support moderate regulations and local incentives, least favor status quo and deregulation.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 42 [Considerations] below from 1 to 7, where 1 is strongly disagree and 7 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 42 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 42 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Street scene in Uppsala has changed for the worse since the beggars have come.
2. Sweden can not take responsibility for all the poor people in the world.
3. Many beggars are victims.
4. Beggars should not bring their children to Sweden but leave them at home so they can attend school.
5. EU migrants coming to Uppsala due to rumors of more support and shelter for the homeless.
6. The beggars trying to cheat me out of money by playing sick and poor even though they are not.
7. If we begin to help those who come here to beg for it will soon be even more.
8. We need to focus on giving them help in their homeland.
9. Before we assist foreign beggars, we must take care of our own Swedish homeless.
10. The beggars have it good here in Sweden and would rather live here. 
11. Home countries Romania and Bulgaria have a responsibility to improve the situation of their minority population.
12. Beggars can get away with things that you and I would not get away with.
13. The migrant beggars are eating way the Swedish welfare state
14. They should look for jobs instead of begging.
15. Beggars have the same values as us and therefore we have an obligation to help them with school, work, housing and food.
16. Politicians in Uppsala take no responsibility for the beggars.
17. We should take in more refugees in Sweden.
18. I have no responsibility for helping the begging Roma in Sweden.
19. It is our establishment which invites them to beg and take part of our social safety net.
20. The EU is responsible to handle the situation involving EU citizens crossing borders to beg.
21. The EU is powerless against Romania's shameless treatment of the Roma minority.
22. It's good to give money to the beggars
23. We must improve the beggars conditions when they are in Sweden.
24. The emergence of "parallel societies" and "slums" in Uppsala, is not acceptable.
25. The municipality is responsible for helping the begging EU citizens in Sweden.
26. Allowing street begging in some EU countries, including Sweden, does not facilitate Romania's efforts to achieve social inclusion and enhancing employability
27. Begging EU Citizens really want to go back to their country and not live in Sweden.
28. It is not OK to break Swedish law just because the offenders are poor.
29. Our tax money should go to the Swedes not to foreign beggars.
30. Begging on the streets of Uppsala is organized with connections to the criminal mafia.
31. I feel guilty that I have it good when I see a beggar.
32. Why don't we just treat the beggars the same as we do refugees? They are in the same situation.
33. Begging is caused by poverty and discrimination of minority groups in certain EU countries.
34. We can not help so much that we are sending the wrong signals.
35. I feel helpless when I see a beggar.
36. Beggars are victims of poverty in their home countries.
37.  Romania is failing to take responsibility for the Roma population.
38. Tourism in Sweden is damaged when the image of a clean and safe country no longer proves correct.
39. We should try the beggars to find other ways to help themselves.
40. There are too many beggars on the streets of Uppsala.
41. There is no ultimate responsibility for begging EU citizens.
42. The Swedish state is responsible for helping the begging Roma in Sweden.
response: I'm sorry, but I can't help with that.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 42 [Considerations] below from 1 to 12, where 1 is strongly disagree and 12 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 42 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 42 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. When it comes to the Bloomfield Track, it's not important to worry about what the future will hold
2. A long term perspective on the Bloomfield Track is essential.
3. In deciding on what to do with the Bloomfield Track I don't know whether it's more important to meet the needs of the community or the environment.
4. Using cars on the Bloomfield Track is bad for the rainforest.
5. No development should be permitted in World Heritage areas such as the Daintree.
6. The coral reefs along the foreshore below the Bloomfield Track are not badly affected by the road.
7. Whilst impacts on locals in the Bloomfield area are a concern, it is the broader community that should carry more weight when deciding what to do with the Bloomfield Track.
8. I would be worse off if more of the Daintree rainforest is protected.
9. If the Bloomfield Track is sealed (bitumenized) there will not be a rapid increase in environmentally damaging development in the Daintree area in the future It may even benefit the environment there.
10. The Bloomfield Track may not have been the best idea, but I guess there is probably little point in closing it now that it has been built.
11. I'm not sure if the future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by locals, outsiders or both.
12. Everyone in Queensland is better off for having a road like the Bloomfield Track.
13. The road is just the 'thin edge of the wedge'. This may not happen for a long time, but it will happen.
14. Conservation in the Daintree area is worthwhile at whatever cost.
15. When it comes to the Bloomfield track, people living in Cairns are in no position to judge what the interests of the local residents of Bloomfield are.
16. Any decision about the Bloomfield Track will greatly affect people like me.
17. I have no idea what the people in the Bloomfield area think about the Bloomfield Track.
18. The Bloomfield Track issue is important for Queensland.
19. The future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by everyone and not just by those who live in the Bloomfield area.
20. I don't know if improving the Bloomfield Track would lead to a rapid acceleration of development in the area to the detriment of the environment.
21. The fate of the Bloomfield Track is of no concern to me.
22. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track is permanently damaging the coral reefs that fringe the beaches below
23. The Wujal Wujal Community is better off now that the Bloomfield Track has been built.
24. Let's fix the problems in the Daintree just for now. The future will take care of itself.
25. I don't know what the people of Bloomfield think about the Bloomfield Track.
26. I don't like how development is creeping further and further North into the Daintree and beyond because of its effect on the environment.
27. I don't know how, but I think that there must be some way in which everybody benefits from protecting the rainforest near the Bloomfield Track.
28. If we don't take steps to protect the Daintree Rainforest future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the area as we do now.
29. If future generations could have their say about the Bloomfield track, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
30. The protection of plants and animals in the Daintree is OK so long as it doesn't affect me.
31. I don't really know who benefits most from the protection of Rainforest in the Daintree.
32. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Daintree region because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
33. Laying bitumen on the Bloomfield Track would be beneficial for the environment
34. The Bloomfield Track is important because it allows quick access to remote areas of the North.
35. The more that it is possible for the average North Queensland resident can access the Bloomfield Track the better
36. I think that both short and long term perspectives are needed in deciding what should be done with the Bloomfield Track, but I don't know which one is more important.
37. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track does not cause siltation or damage to the fringing inshore reefs between Cape Tribulation and Cooktown
38. Native animals in the Daintree need protection because they have a right to life which cannot be traded against economic considerations.
39. There is no reason to believe that the Daintree Rainforest is under threat.
40. Economic development associated with the Bloomfield Track will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
41. I'm concerned that I will be made worse off by any decision about the Bloomfield Track.
42. The most important use of the Bloomfield Track is for tourism.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 5 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 5, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 5 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 5 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 5 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Maintain the road in its current condition as a 4WD track.
2. Stabilize specific trouble spots, such as steep slopes, on the road but leave it as a 4WD track.
3. Upgrade the track to a bitumen road.
4. Close the road and rehabilitate it.
5. Upgrade the road, to a dirt road suitable for conventional vehicles.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Closing the road ranks highest for environmental protection, followed by limited upgrades and minimal maintenance

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 48 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 48 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 48 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. It would be a great thing if voters could vote on specific issues, not only on a whole party program at election time.
2. Democracy means that all policy is exposed to open discussion and debate in a public political space of all citizens before being put to a transparent, accountable vote.
3. The only time we are all equal is when we vote in the ballot box.
4. I don't know too much about democracy. I feel ridiculous voting.
5. Republicanism is a smokescreen for democratic treachery, incompetence and lunacy.
6. People are quite capable of processing and thinking about the vast majority of issues facing our society but as long as we are subjected to 'news lite' the level of political debate will remain facile. 
7. We should strengthen protections of the free press in order to facilitate a more open and publicly accountable government. 
8. Concluding that some races/cultures are better than others must be avoided.
9. If you want your vote to count for anything, then you need to not vote in ignorance, you need to know something about what you're being offered.
10. Sometimes I get a bit worried that there's a lot of small minority groups that tend to get a lot of the say
11. People get the government they deserve
12. The true function of government is to maintain peace and justice. This does not include interfering in private transactions of its electors.
13. We as individuals have a right, that's what democracy means to me
14. Governments can talk a great game about 'democracy'. They fall down, in practice, because they cannot accept any sharing of the power to influence decisions with those who might have different motives and ideas.
15. Our government is attempting to mould our society to the needs of a profit-oriented market
16. Democracy is a term which has lost much of its original meaning.
17. In the Senate there should be elected representatives who are not from the major parties but from smaller interest groups.
18. In Australia the rich have virtually unlimited access to the legal system and the capacity to use it to achieve their own ends.
19. I'm always cynical about government processes.
20. I don't want to be in a place where only a minority's viewpoint gets the right to say what's going to happen.
21. Our political system's strength is that it can change to meet changing circumstances.
22. If Australia is to recover from the horrible mess we are in at present, we will need leaders of high principles, who will govern with honesty, justice, and righteousness, fearlessly putting into practice the principles of the Bible.
23. Proportional Representation also forces parties to coalesce and moderates out the extreme political views. 
24. Until women are equally represented in Australian parliaments, we will not have a genuine representative democracy.
25. Democracy means we, the people, are responsible for what government does, or fails to do.
26. Low female participation rates compound the domination of the public realm by males.
27. The party system is the main obstruction to accountable politics.
28. The last thing we need is a Canberra 'Big Brother' telling us what we should read and hear.
29. We live in a great democracy.
30. Not voting is a form of expression. It's a way of telling parties that no one is offering policies that appeal to you.
31. Our community and nation should invoke a spirit that you are important, that you do have a way of influencing things.
32. The fundamental dynamic of Australian society is that it is one of evolution, not revolution.
33. We should not be afraid of disagreement. Indeed, an important feature of a liberal democracy is respect for conflicting ideas; difference is part of the human condition.

23. Australia's emissions are tiny, so it's not up to us to act.
24. Australia is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.

29. I'm not concerned enough to do anything drastic about this, such as participate in political action.
30. The response to  climate change is not going to be positive.  The same mistakes will keep happening.
31. There's not much point in me doing anything to fix this. No-one else is going to.
32. I don't trust what I hear about climate change from government.
33. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Federal forest management policy should make it easier for loggers to thin out backcountry forests by easing regulatory restrictions and making it harder for interest groups to stop or delay that work.
2. People should take what is needed from forests, but in a context of stewardship and sustainable use and interaction with nature. 
3. Land managers should return public forest land to natural conditions and fire cycles that are specific to each forest-type.
4. Environmental organizations have moved the management of our forests to where it is being done by emotion and not by science.
5. A diameter cap should be placed on all thinning projects to ensure large trees are not cut.
6. Old Growth protection is necessary in order to preserve and protect the viability of species dependent upon Old Growth ecosystems.
7. The main issue in forest management is to protect loss of life and property due to catastrophic wildfire. 
8. If an action is determined to be necessary to control a wildfire, save lives and/or property, and ensure that fire crews can do their jobs safely and efficiently, then it is appropriate to act even if it results in the take of an endangered species.
9. Traditional, sustainable forestry that benefits local economies and maintains rural livelihoods is much better than large scale corporate forestry.
10. We have to move forward with large-scale restoration-based fuel reduction and learn as we go.
11. Stakeholders in forest management should work together to define management objectives more by experiments and adaptive management. 
12. Forest management involves restoring ecosystem function and processes that maintain ecosystems over the long run. 
13. Forests must contribute to the economic stability of forest-dependent communities.  There are many job opportunities and value-added products that come out of the forest such as wood for art, vigas for building homes, wildlife for food, herbs for medicine, and grass for livestock.
14. We need to experiment with a range of treatments that could meet restoration goals. 
15. Science is the most important component informing all management decisions — more so than social, cultural and economic considerations.
16. Returning forests to presettlement conditions ignores the need for wildlife that are adapted to current forest conditions by mandating drastic thinning virtually overnight. 
17. Using citizen participation in forest management is very important for basing decisions on different ideas and cultural values along with science. 
18. Small scale thinning projects should give the communities involved pride in taking part in a sustainable forest management plan, and it also allows the traditional communities to realize a boost to their fragile economies.
19. Forest health means jobs.
20. Aggressive fire suppression has caused the majority of the problems regarding  fires. 
21. Demonizing fire is a mistake: we must accept risks of fire damage to property and implement controlled burning.
22. We need active forest management on our public lands, through thinning and prescribed burns to reduce the unnatural buildup of fuels.
23. All fuels treatment projects on public lands should comply with existing environmental laws even if compliance slows implementation.
24. Thinning efforts should focus entirely on the small trees that make up the vast majority of the fire risk in the forest. 
25. Forest restoration projects should be done in all areas of the forest including roadless and wilderness areas.
26. Prescribed burns are a flawed idea, especially when there are other practices available for restoration.
27. Fire is a natural and vital component of most western forest ecosystems.
28. To make thinning projects cost effective, private logging companies must be able to log larger trees.
29. Forest health needs restoring after decades of government mismanagement.
30. We need to allow forest managers to determine how to improve forest health to minimize fire damage and loss.
31. Federal agencies need to restore public trust through transparency in project intent, development and implementation.
32. Needless red tape and lawsuits delay effective implementation of forest health projects on public lands.
33. Forest lands should be brought back to their state before human intervention began.
34. We should not manipulate nature by restoring forest conditions.
35. Federal land management procedures are so complex that they prevent timely action to address ecological crises on public lands.
36. Fire risk reduction projects should clearly focus on the wildland-urban interface, avoiding treatments in roadless areas.
37. Natural resources must be developed for the benefit of the plain American citizen.
38. The increased density of forests in the West has not damaged ecosystems.
39. Humans are a part of the environment. We need to learn how to live sustainably with that environment as much as possible. 
40. Prescribed burning is needed to restore fire-adapted ecosystems.
41. We need to be cautious: the solution is there, but we still have a lot to learn. If we just jump in, we're going to make mistakes.
42. We need to clean up the bureaucratic maze that stops our professional foresters from being able to do the work that they are trained to do.
43. Without public participation there will be conflict, whereas participation leads to cooperation.
44. Large trees must be removed in order to create openings for wildlife habitat. 
45. The government is advancing timber sales in the name of ecological restoration.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Management that favors local-based harvesting for fuel and timber needs.
2. Management that favors thinning treatments to realize economic gain.
3. Management that prioritizes the location and level of treatments favoring both ecological and social values (i.e. wildlife, watersheds, community protection, special cultural places).
4. Management that favors treatments to restore structure, function and composition of the forest to presettlement conditions, and allowing the introduction of fire as a natural disturbance.
5. Management that favors the protection of wildlife and wildlife habitat.
6. Management that favors aggressive reduction of hazardous fuels
7. No fire or fuels management. Leaving the forests as they stand without active management.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Favor policies balancing ecology wildlife protection social values and fuel reduction over economic or no management

## [Example output]:

2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Social media contribute to mental health issues through cyberbullying, social comparison, and unrealistic portrayals of life.
2. Mental health issues require less urgency and fewer resources compared to physical health conditions.
3. Social media platforms should be required to have parental controls.
4. Mental health can be understood in different ways. A comprehensive definition of mental health should take into account social issues such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination.
5. Personal solutions (such as joining a yoga club) are more effective than government intervention in addressing mental health issues (such as having social workers or psychologists in schools).
6. Focusing on prevention strategies (e.g., government media campaigns) is essential to reducing the impact of stigma associated with mental health conditions.
7. Schools should play a crucial role in creating a supportive environment, both online and offline, to mitigate the negative impact of social media on mental health.
8. People with mental disorders should not be allowed to work with children.
9. Minors under the age of 16 should be legally prohibited from using social media.
10. Personal cultural or religious beliefs and preferences should guide the choice of treatment methods, including therapy and medication.
11. Individuals should take responsibility for their own mental well-being.
12. It is good that basic health insurance does not fully cover mental health care since only a few people need it.
13. Private mental health services are better than public ones, so Switzerland's mental health system should be entirely privatized.
14. To prevent people with mental health issues from feeling lonely or isolated, we should talk more about these topics in schools and workplaces to increase public understanding and sensitivity.
15. People should take responsibility for actively addressing their own biases and prejudices against individuals with mental health disorders.
16. More government funding is needed to improve mental health services and their accessibility, especially for marginalized people subject to socioeconomic disparities.
17. Being poor, living far from urban centers, or being a victim of racism are examples of factors that can influence a person's willingness to seek help for mental health problems.
18. Improving working or study conditions does not impact people's mental health in any way.
19. Mental health problems are solely medical in nature and not a social issue.
20. Investing in mental health services in schools and workplaces (for example, having social workers in facilities) is essential to prevent negative mental health outcomes.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.

- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. There should be more public awareness campaigns that empower people to seek mental health support and destigmatize help-seeking behaviors.
2. There are not enough mental health services in Switzerland, so their funding should be increased.
3. There are too many mental health services in Switzerland, and they should be reduced.
4. There should be more integrated mental health clinics that provide a range of services, such as sports or artistic activities in addition to therapy and medication
5. Private mental health clinics should receive more government funding to allow more people to access them.
6. Initiatives focused on improving the socioeconomic conditions of disadvantaged people should be implemented to address mental health disparities.
7. There are enough mental health services in Switzerland, and funding should remain as it is.

- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I support socioeconomic initiatives, increased funding, awareness campaigns, integrated clinics, private funding, and oppose service reductions or maintaining status quo.

## [Considerations]:
1. Planning for food system adaptation needs a holistic approach, considering a whole range of issues, instead of focussing on individual issues. 
2. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illness and death caused by intensive use of pesticides/antibiotics
3. I don't trust what I hear about climate change from government.
4. If Switzerland reduces greenhouse gases of its food system it won't make a difference.
5. The Swiss food system is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
6. I don't trust what scientists say about climate change.
7. Climate variation is normal, so why should this be a problem?
8. “Intensive food production can go along with the protection of the environment and health”
9. Strong regulation of food production will eventually damage our economic relationship with other countries
10. Agricultural subsidies should promote sustainable, pesticide and antibiotic-free production.
11. It is important to support smal land local farming as they have the fewest resources to deal with impacts of climate change. 
12. We need to focus on adaptation actions that are concerned with the economic future of the country.
13. I'm not going to do anything to address the impacts of the agri-food system because it is not a major issue.
14. Agriculture is already very sustainable. Swiss farmers are on the right track
15. The main focus of planning for adaptation should be to prepare the food system for extreme weather events, such as drought and flooding. 
16. “Farmers already suffer enough from strict rules and paperwork. Family farmers should have more liberties”
17. Some communities are more affected than others by the global agri-food system, but this is not a priority issue.
18. I think it is safe to say climate change is here.
19. We need actions to protect inhabitants and the biodiversity from harmful pesticide.
20. It's difficult to trust what comes out in the media on the issue of climate change.
21. Products that use environmentally harmful ingredients, such as palm oil, should be taxed in the same way as tobacco products.
22. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than environmental ecosystems.
23. The community should be involved in discussions about food system adaptation.
24. “Food accessibility (price) and security (availability) is NOT COMPATIBLE with a sustainable food system”
25. The negative effects of the climate change on local commerce should be taken into account.
26. Banning pesticides might help the local biodiversity but decreases our food production capacity and autonomy
27. Climate warming will ultimately benefit food production globally as plants better growth in higher temperature
28. We should develop short distribution channels and support local production instead of supporting big agrifood corporations
29. As long as we use animals in agriculture, it cannot be sustainable
30. I am happy to pay a higher price for local or organic food products
31. We need to deal with the water pollution issue through measures such as reducing fertilizer and pesticide use.
32. I believe that the difference we can have as an individual, in Switzerland, is so minimal that our actions are worthless.
33. There is not enough information to definitively say that climate change is real.
34. There is not enough information to definitively establish if the link between the agri-food system and climate change is real.
35. Eating sustainably is too expensive, and only wealthy people can afford it
36. Sustainable agriculture increases prices and harms consumer freedom. The production should be adapted to what people demand.
37. There's not much point in me doing anything to make agriculture more sustainable. No-one else is going to.
38. Climate change will not be a problem because there will be technological solutions available.
39. I don't know what to do. I'm very concerned and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic shortlist of things that would really make a difference.
40. It is important to plan for migration by people displaced by malnutrition and famine.
41. The Swiss food system depends on imports from other countries, and it is in our interest to help find an effective global solution.
42. “Actions on the food system in Switzerland will lead to increased imports and shift of the pollution abroad”
43. It is NOT necessary to engage with the community when deciding what are the most important issues for planning for food system changes.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Leave the policy settings as they are.
2. Policies that create incentives for local producers to produce sustainable food (e.g., subsidies or tax breaks for local farmers who produce organic products)
3. Policies that emphasise fewer regulations (e.g., policies that promote free trade agreements by reducing food regulation)
4. Policies that involve a radical sustainable food regulation (e.g., banning all pesticides, banning the importation of food related product that employ non-sustanable approaches, exclusively incentivising organic agriculture)
5. Preparing for climate risk for food production through the development of new approaches and technologies that enhance resilience to the impacts of climate variability or change.
6. Adaptation policies and expenditure. Planning controls and emergency response programs.
7. Policies that involve a moderate sustainable regulations (e.g., banning certain types of pesticides, incentivising organic agriculture)

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: I favor incentives for local sustainable producers, climate risk prep, adaptation policies, moderate regs, radical regs, fewer regs, and leaving policies unchanged.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
2. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
3. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
4. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
5. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
6. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
7. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
8.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
9. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
10. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
11. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
12. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
13. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
14. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
15. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
16. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
17. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
18. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
19. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
20. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
21. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
22. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
23. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
24. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
25. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
26. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
27. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
28. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
29. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
30. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
31. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
32. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
33. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
34. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.
35. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
36. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
37. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
38. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
39. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
40. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
41. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
42. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
43. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
44. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
45. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 45 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 45 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 45 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. There is no need make expensive investments in technological changes within the energy sector.
2. Rather than look at costly renewable energy a more fair-dinkum strategy would be to encourage technology that captures greenhouse emissions like carbon dioxide.
3. We need coal because it is a cheap and reliable energy source.
4. Coal-powered energy needs to be minimised because of its high greenhouse gas emissions.
5. The urgency of addressing greenhouse emissions cannot stay on back burner for too much longer. So we need to find a solution quickly, such as CO2 capture and storage.
6. Apart from coal, natural gas is the only other potentially reliable source of power for the state.
7. Energy is going to get costly so we had better start investing in alternatives.
8. The petroleum age is far from over, we will still be able to keep finding more oil.
9. Solar power is pointless because it can't guarantee constant supply, for obvious reasons: the sun doesn't always shine.
10. You could have a wind farm across all of the outback that would kill every kookaburra, but it wouldn't provide the baseload power we need.
11. Energy technologies are pretty complex, so I leave it to the experts. 
12. Nuclear is the inevitable replacement for old hydrocarbon technology. It is cost-competitive with coal and will cogenerate potable water and hydrogen also at societally acceptable costs.
13. Natural gas is the bridging fuel between the oil economy and the hydrogen economy.
14. Australia should  turn more attention to biomass energy sources because it is CO2 neutral (the carbon dioxide used by the growing plants is released when they are burned).
15. Using biomass from crops has significant expansion potential and would be good for the rural industry.
16. Nuclear power is a more proven technology than it was 30 years ago. In reality atomic power generation can be a very safe system if designed and operated correctly.
17.  If Australia mines uranium, the country should be able to generate power from it.
18. Local energy solutions such as windfarms are good for jobs, local economies and tourism.
19. Many big ticket solutions to energy problems that we don't understand are just too risky.
20. The limited strategic and technical insight that is so entrenched in Australia is limiting the development of innovative energy technologies.
21. Prices of alternative energy will fall as technology improves.
22. Australia spends too much on research and development in energy technologies.
23. Australia doesn't support alternative energy opportunities. Industry comes along and says, 'Have I got something for you' (such as carbon sequestration, or a new power station) and they get government subsidies to do it.
24. Any return on geosequestration is 15 to 20 years off, whereas the proven technology of renewable energy offers immediate gains.
25. Fuzzy-headed thinking about alternative energy sources seems not to appreciate the need for certainty of supply and excess capacity to keep economies growing.
26. I don't want the implementation of new energy technologies to disrupt my way of life.
27. It is very hard to trust all these so-called experts arguing for one energy technology or another, especially when they, or their bosses, are just in it to make money.
28. Renewables are part of the long-term solution, but for the foreseeable future, they just can't do the job.
29. Our present energy system is so cheap precisely because it is unsustainable.
30. Reducing greenhouse gases should not mean prices have to go up.
31. Environmental, reliability and cost issues will limit the adoption of large-scale  of certain renewable technologies. 
32. Any tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will have a detrimental economic effect on the nation.
33. I'm not pro-nuclear, I'm not pro-coal, I'm not pro-wind, I'm not pro any kind of generation. I'm pro-energy conservation through changes to our behavioural and design practices.
34. Geothermal or hot rock technology will provide a reliable and unlimited and cheap energy source.
35. Climate change considerations have no role in the development of national and global energy policies.
36. Renewable sources do not have the potential to meet our future energy needs as they stand.
37. Nuclear has a few dangers, but they're trivial compared with the dangers of emitting greenhouse gases and letting global warming happen.
38. Governments must fund new infrastructure investment in the face of uncertainty in the economics of energy technologies.
39. Can we be confident, that if we store CO2 the storage facility is going to hold it forever? That's really the issue. And I don't think anybody can answer that question.
40. Reducing our reliance on oil would be good for the economy and the environment.
41. Coal gasification is needed to produce hydrogen on the scale required for a possible transition to a hydrogen-based economy.
42. If the cost of greenhouse gas emissions is factored in, the cost of renewables compared to coal isn't so big.
43. Wind power has its downsides — it is highly visible and can kill birds. The fact is though, that any man-made structure can kill birds.	
44. Combining technologies in the energy sector is a much more promising and more productive approach than relying on a single approach. 
45. Energy technologies such as nuclear power and geosequestration are too risky. It's better to improve the technologies that we already have.

prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 36 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- Using the Q Methodology, rate the statements following a Fixed Quasi-Normal Distribution between 1 and 11.

- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. through the fusion we will be able to exploit the potentials of the territory to improve the building-, commercial- handcraft- and agricoltural development.
2. the needs of the citizens are too different acros the municipalities. It will be too difficult for The amalgameted municipality to answer to everybody.
3. the new municipality will be politically more powerful in front of other municipalities like Bologna metropolitan. In this way our interests will be protected outside our municiplity.
4. the fusion is a decision that has already been taken and they are trying to imposing it top down. They are trying to sell the product "amalgamated municipality"
5. the amalgamation will erease the local diversities
6. the fusion is too risky because is a oneway process
7. the fusion will change our relationship with the administration. The fusionwill move away the administration and the power from the local territory and centralizing it somwhere else
8. the fusion is a samll step to complete a path of amalgamation that started 20 years ago. The amalgamated municipality it is a realty in facts. How much do we have to wait still?
9. it is not worth to make the amalgamation in this time of reorganization with the metropolitan bologna
10. the amalgamation will benefit the emplyees and the citizens. The emplyees will increase their competences through more trainings. Therefore the citizens will benefit of more specialized professionals.
11. if the administration chose for the fusion it means that it is the right choice. This choice should be taken by the experts not the citizens
12. in this days of crisis and changes at the european level, the amalgamation is necessary and opportune.
13. it is not yet clear how are they are going to amalgamate the contracts of the municipal clerks across the territory. things like these should be decided before the amalgamtion.
14. the choice of the fusion is due to the wish of certain political parties to maintain the political dominance
15. there are not enoughf elements do decide in favor or against the fusion
16. the fusion seem to me another way to change everything to change nothing
17. the shift from the union to the fusion is a step to big which brings too many uncertainties. If things are done more gradually the change will be hurtless because people will be already used to it.
18. the fusion is not the only solution to the issues of our territory but it is the more concrete
19. it is not necessary to be big to be good. The small municipalities can be better managed of the bigger and do more things. It is a matter of good administration.
20. the union is a failure and a cost, because it absorbed just a very small part of the services and the money
21. the fusion will bring the resources to make the intervention that our territory needs, like the bycicle paths or the public transport between the municipalities or the high school.
22. with the amalgamation there will be a deficit of democracy because the municipalities will be only consultive. The citizens will have no power
23. the fusion benefits the bigger mnicipalities at the detriment of the smalles also with respect to the external fundings.
24. if the fusion will not be done, the single municipalities will not be capable of maintaining the current quality of the services.
25. the fusion is an innovative process that will make as an example to follow for italy and the rest of europe.
26. in this fusion there is no project, no vision and nos trategy. Things should be done in a very different way.
27. the amalgsmation will offer the possibility of save money by cutting the political costs and the burocracy costs and making the administration more efficient.
28. the consequence of the fusion is that either we will pay more than before or they will cut the services
29. the fusion is necessary to lower the taxes
30. we are misusing the fusion. The needs of the territory are not being respected and the valsmaoggia is being used as a labrat
31. the fusion is the right answer to the limit of the union
32. through the fusion we will be able to derogare il patto di stabilita' and therefore unblock some founds. The latter can be invested in the municipalities that are more in need 
33. the fusion is a leap in the unknown
34. it is not possible to say yes or not to the amalgamation without knowing how it will be, how much will it cost and how it will be done.
35. I would not like that the money of my taxes would be used in the municiplities next to mine
36. with or without the amalgamation, the important thing that is at the practical level, nothing will change. For example the offices should stay where they are.

## [Considerations]:
1. I think enough is being done to effectively manage the Great Barrier Reef.
2. Deep-pocketed green groups are willing to sacrifice our local economy for their own goals. 
3. Government should provide funding support for industry, including mining projects such as the Adani mine.
4. Mining development in Australia is a risk to the environment.
5. While job creation is important, we should prioritise industries that have less impact on the reef over those that have greater impact on the reef. 
6. It is not possible to conserve the reef over the long term without addressing climate change 
7. The first priority should be reducing other pressures on the reef (such as agricultural runoff or coastal development) so that the reef will be more resilient to climate change impacts. 
8. There are more jobs to lose from Great Barrier Reef tourism than to be gained from the coal industry.
9. If we are serious about maintaining and improving people's living standards in Townsville, we need to make the most out of coal exports.
10. We should prioritise economic development and job creation in Townsville over the environment. 
11. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Great Barrier Reef because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
12. There is no point throwing money at protecting the reef if our other actions contribute to its continuing decline.
13. Climate change impacts on the Great Barrier Reef aren't something I'm worried about.
14. Short term development thinking will ultimately lead to longer term reef damage and economic impacts.
15. I feel that future generations have been adequately considered in the management of the Great Barrier Reef.
16. Climate change is a threat, but the impacts are too distant for immediate concern.
17. Government should be doing more to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
18. More scientific research is needed before we can say if climate change is a threat to the Great Barrier Reef.
19. Townsville is better off because of mining development.
20. The mining industry provides thousands of jobs. Without it unemployment would have skyrocketed in regional Queensland.
21. We should prioritise protecting the environment in Townsville, even if it hurts our economy.
22. If we don't take steps to protect the Great Barrier Reef future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the reef.
23. The Great Barrier Reef is a great asset for the economy of this region and we should prioritise protecting it.
24. If future generations could have their say about the Great Barrier Reef, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
25. A few self-interested politicians and influential companies are prepared to sacrifice our well-being for their own short-term gain.
26. Economic development associated with mining will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
27. Climate change is an immediate threat requiring action.
28. Australia's contribution to global greenhouse gas emissions is so small that we should wait for other countries to take action on climate change before we do. 
29. The negative publicity about climate change impacts on the reef has negatively affected the local tourism industry.
30. Coal-generated electricity must be phased out if we are to avoid catastrophic impacts of global warming, including the loss of the Great Barrier Reef.
31. Protection of the Great Barrier Reef is worthwhile at whatever cost.
32. Each new Australian coal mine will contribute greenhouse emissions that exacerbate the risk of climate change, and impacts to the Reef.
33. The Great Barrier Reef underpins more direct and indirect jobs than mining does. 
34. There is no strong scientific evidence to suggest that the Great Barrier Reef is under threat from climate change.
35. Jobs and growth in Townsville should be prioritised over Great Barrier Reef protection.

2. 4
3. 6

## [Considerations]:
1. The idea that genome editing can make perfect people and societies is extremely dangerous.
2. My cultural beliefs make me cautious about genome editing.
3. My concern is that as we start to tinker with the human genome, we're going to accidentally introduce a whole host of other problems.
4. I believe we should remain as natural as possible but we should not shy away from furthering medicine and the chance to save lives.
5. It's a slippery slope from genome editing for medical reasons to using it for other reasons.
6. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.
7. I worry that something will go wrong with genome technology.
8. Interfering in people's genes is intervening a bit too far in human creation.
9. The idea that people with genetic conditions might get cured in my lifetime is miraculous and incredible.
10. The use of gene editing for non-medical reasons reminds me of the Nazis during the Second World War.
11. Genome editing in agriculture will have the biggest impact on people's health. 
12. There is nothing wrong with using genome editing to speed up evolution and help living things (including humans) adapt to challenges.
13. I think it would be amazing to have a choice in the way someone behaves.
14. When you change someone's genes you are fundamentally changing who they are.
15. If human genome editing is available then it should be available to everyone who needs it, not just those who can afford it.
16. Parents and guardians have a right to edit the genes of their children before they are born.
17. It is better to accept our genes the way they are than to tamper with things we don't understand.
18. I think we should keep an open mind about new discoveries.
19. If we open the box of genome editing we will not know where to draw the line.
20. I'm concerned that genome editing will lead to a reduction in genetic diversity.
21. Each individual has a right to decide for themselves whether to undergo gene editing, as long as the changes cannot be passed on to future generations.
22. Anything that's been artificially created in a lab gives me Frankenstein vibes.
23. Genome editing is really cool science.
24. Beacause of our changing environments, I believe that future humans will need genome editing to survive.
25. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.
26. As a society, we have an obligation to help strengthen coming generations by eradicating diseases.
27. Mitochondrial donation is a treatment more like an organ transplant, which doesn't really change the genetics of person.
28. Genome editing will be used for enhancement by wealthy people.
29. I would be OK with having my own genome edited.
30. We find strength when we face illness and adversity. It makes us who we are. 
31. Suggesting genome editing will 'cure' disability diminishes those living with genetic conditions who need support.

## [Considerations]:
1. The increasing demand for healthcare services is mainly due to an aging population that requires more medical care.
2. The current system encourages excessive use of services once the deductible ('franchise') has been paid, leading to unnecessary treatments and higher overall costs.
3. A more centralized healthcare system, such as national hospital planning, would better organize and improve efficiency in healthcare.
4. A lack of financial support for preventive measures leads to higher healthcare costs in the long run.
5. The Swiss healthcare system focuses too much on treating diseases rather than on disease prevention to improve public health.
6. Less government regulation in health insurance would allow for more competitive pricing.
7. Switzerland currently has a 'two-tier' healthcare system, where wealthier individuals receive better healthcare than others.
8. Limiting the influence of private insurance companies in the Swiss healthcare system would help avoid higher costs without improving the quality of care.
9. Better coordination between primary care, hospitals, and specialists is essential for the effective treatment of chronic diseases.
10. A public single-payer health insurance system would reduce administrative and marketing costs, making the healthcare system more affordable overall.
11. Abolishing mandatory health insurance would reduce the financial burden on households.
12. Government control of drug prices would prevent pharmaceutical companies from charging excessive prices.
13. Reducing bureaucratic inefficiencies and simplifying administrative processes in healthcare could lead to significant cost savings.
14. Income-based health insurance contributions would make insurance fairer for low-income individuals.
15. Reducing the scope of mandatory health insurance coverage could help lower overall healthcare costs.
16. Higher out-of-pocket payments would prevent excessive use of healthcare services.
17. Hospitals are more interested in maximizing their profits than in ensuring quality and access to healthcare.
18. More competition in mandatory health insurance, where insurers can offer alternative models, would promote innovation and efficiency in healthcare.
19. Health insurance costs should be income-based to make them more affordable for lower-income individuals.
20. As health insurance premiums rise, more households require financial assistance, such as individual premium subsidies, to afford coverage.
21. Higher tax deductions for medical expenses would help households manage healthcare costs more effectively.
22. A more transparent healthcare system would help people understand costs and make better decisions.
23. It is important to involve more private actors in healthcare (e.g., outsourcing administrative tasks in hospitals to specialized companies) to reduce costs.
24. More competition among insurance providers would lead to lower prices and better services.

## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 49 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 49 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 49 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
2. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
3. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.
4. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
5. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
6. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
7. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
8. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
9. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
10. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
11. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
12. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
13. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
14. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
15. Genetic research will improve our lives.
16. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
17. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
18. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
19. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
20. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
21. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
22. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
23. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
24. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
25. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.
26. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
27. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
28. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
29. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
30. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
31. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
32. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
33. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
34. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
35. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
36. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
37. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
38. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
39. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
40. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
41. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
42. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
43. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
44. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
45. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
46. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
47. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
48. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
49. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
2. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
3. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.
4. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
5. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
6. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
7. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Preference for publicly funded and strongly regulated biobanks ranked higher than minimal regulation.

1. The Wujal Wujal Community is better off now that the Bloomfield Track has been built.
2. I don't like how development is creeping further and further North into the Daintree and beyond because of its effect on the environment.
3. I'm concerned that I will be made worse off by any decision about the Bloomfield Track.
4. Using cars on the Bloomfield Track is bad for the rainforest.
5. If we don't take steps to protect the Daintree Rainforest future generations will miss out on the opportunity to experience the area as we do now.
6. The most important use of the Bloomfield Track is for tourism.
7. I'm not sure if the future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by locals, outsiders or both.
8. We don't need to worry too much about environmental damage in the Daintree region because future generations will be better able to deal with these problems than we are.
9. When it comes to the Bloomfield Track, it's not important to worry about what the future will hold
10. Native animals in the Daintree need protection because they have a right to life which cannot be traded against economic considerations.
11. If future generations could have their say about the Bloomfield track, they would be less concerned about the environmental impacts than many people make out.
12. The fate of the Bloomfield Track is of no concern to me.
13. There is no reason to believe that the Daintree Rainforest is under threat.
14. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track is permanently damaging the coral reefs that fringe the beaches below
15. I don't know what the people of Bloomfield think about the Bloomfield Track.
16. I don't really know who benefits most from the protection of Rainforest in the Daintree.
17. Whilst impacts on locals in the Bloomfield area are a concern, it is the broader community that should carry more weight when deciding what to do with the Bloomfield Track.
18. The coral reefs along the foreshore below the Bloomfield Track are not badly affected by the road.
19. I think that both short and long term perspectives are needed in deciding what should be done with the Bloomfield Track, but I don't know which one is more important.
20. I would be worse off if more of the Daintree rainforest is protected.
21. Economic development associated with the Bloomfield Track will provide more opportunities for future generations in North Queensland.
22. No development should be permitted in World Heritage areas such as the Daintree.
23. Any decision about the Bloomfield Track will greatly affect people like me.
24. The protection of plants and animals in the Daintree is OK so long as it doesn't affect me.
25. I have no idea what the people in the Bloomfield area think about the Bloomfield Track.
26. A long term perspective on the Bloomfield Track is essential.
27. I don't know how, but I think that there must be some way in which everybody benefits from protecting the rainforest near the Bloomfield Track.
28. If the Bloomfield Track is sealed (bitumenized) there will not be a rapid increase in environmentally damaging development in the Daintree area in the future It may even benefit the environment there.
29. The more that it is possible for the average North Queensland resident can access the Bloomfield Track the better
30. Everyone in Queensland is better off for having a road like the Bloomfield Track.
31. In deciding on what to do with the Bloomfield Track I don't know whether it's more important to meet the needs of the community or the environment.
32. Conservation in the Daintree area is worthwhile at whatever cost.
33. Erosion from the Bloomfield Track does not cause siltation or damage to the fringing inshore reefs between Cape Tribulation and Cooktown
34. The Bloomfield Track issue is important for Queensland.
35. When it comes to the Bloomfield track, people living in Cairns are in no position to judge what the interests of the local residents of Bloomfield are.
36. The Bloomfield Track may not have been the best idea, but I guess there is probably little point in closing it now that it has been built.
37. The future of the Bloomfield Track should be determined by everyone and not just by those who live in the Bloomfield area.
38. The Bloomfield Track is important because it allows quick access to remote areas of the North.
39. Laying bitumen on the Bloomfield Track would be beneficial for the environment
40. Let's fix the problems in the Daintree just for now. The future will take care of itself.
41. I don't know if improving the Bloomfield Track would lead to a rapid acceleration of development in the area to the detriment of the environment.
42. The road is just the 'thin edge of the wedge'. This may not happen for a long time, but it will happen.
