prompt:
## Instructions:
- Rate each of the 49 [Considerations] below from 1 to 11, where 1 is strongly disagree and 11 is strongly agree.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 49 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 49 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
2. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
3. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
4. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
5. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
6. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
7. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
8. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
9. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
10. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
11. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
12. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
13. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
14. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
15. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
16. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
17. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
18. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.
19. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
20. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.
21. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
22. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
23. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
24. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
25. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.
26. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
27. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
28. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
29. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
30. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
31. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
32. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
33. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
34. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
35. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
36. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.
37. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
38. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
39. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
40. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
41. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
42. Genetic research will improve our lives.
43. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
44. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
45. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
46. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
47. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
48. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
49. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
2. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
3. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.
4. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
5. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
6. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
7. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Favor public funding with strong regulation and high privacy, prefer strict oversight over minimal regulation.
